author: kareemb
title: Decentralizied Farm to Table
description: En este momento, los agricultores y las colectividades están fragmentados y son demasiado difíciles de manejar para el ciudadano medio que quiere una buena comida local y saludable.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposer aims to create a DAO for farmers and collective. In general I very much like this idea. This challenge is asking for solution that will help to make Cardano the go-to-blockchain for DAOs. Comparing the challenge setting with the goals of the proposals I don't see a full alignment between challenge and proposal. Even tough this idea is interesting and has my support I don't see enough explanation on why this should be funded under this challenge and how it will positively impact the growth of Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan for implementation is only roughly described. Also the scope of the project doesn't get clear as details about technical implementation or basic underlying mechanism are missing. 
Also there is not real proof of life of the proposer team nor references about relevant experience. By the given information it is not comprehensible how this will be done. The budget is broken down and linked to the planned activites.
f6_assessments.q2: The presents a time horizon and has defined success criteria. A documentation source to track the progress of this proposal is missing. I miss in this area that the proposer has not mentioned possible difficulties for the development and implementation. Creating this DAO is one thing, but how can you make sure that it will be used and will get traction?

f6_assessments.q0: The aim of the proposal is to create a DAO of farmers to e.g. decrease costs or raise funds. Even tough the DAO establishment is in accordance with the challenge goal, I find its impact questionable, due to the "proof of concept" which this proposal claims to be. On the other hand, it might be a driver for a different type of people to join the cryptoverse and the impact can be unexpectedly large.
f6_assessments.q1: The budget requires more details regarding the time frame to assess whether it is reasonably set. Also, the proposer is described, but the team members (devs) are missing, so or they do not exist, or they were not stated.
f6_assessments.q2: The problem is not clearly stated - the start of the proposal contains "it is hard for consumer to navigate among farmers" and I am not sure how it helps by developing a DAO when the aim of DAO is to decrease costs, organize, raise funds etc. The problem-solution is somehow confusing. Regarding KPIs  - unfortunately, there is no information about these. The roadmap requires more details and it needs to be divided into more items for the purpose of the audit.

f6_assessments.q0: The Proposer wants to set up an autonomous regional Farmer Collective to ensure that standards are enforced ; there is authenticity and lowered costs. Their intention of bringing small farmers together to have a common aim on block chain is laudable.
f6_assessments.q1: The lead is an experienced farmer with over 15 years in farming logistics and an entrepreneur. His team has access to a nationwide network of 3000 regenerative agriculture farms. They will be a supplier force and can definitely implement the proposal successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The road map is clear showing 3 months, and 6 months and above timeline with specific schedules. The budget is broken down into details and also mentioned measurable facts in the proposal.. Recommended.

f6_assessments.q0:
I love this idea! The global food distribution system is very unfair to farmers. This is an issue that my family has been looking at for several years, as weekly buyers of organic vegetables from Riverford, a UK supplier that buys from independent suppliers, and tries to offer them a good deal.

Making this type of arrangement more broadly accessible through a DAO is a very interesting idea. I expect that it will be challenging to capture the many aspects of food distribution in a DAO, but it is a simpler system than some and we need to start somewhere. Perhaps the proposer will be able to start with simpler aspects of the system and eventually move more of the operation to a DAO.

Bottom line is that this fits the challenge extremely well, and addresses a genuine and important problem.
f6_assessments.q1: Although I love this proposal, and the proposer has relevant experience, the details of how the proposal would be executed are not specified. As mentioned under impact, it will be challenging to turn the food distribution system into a DAO, and the proposal does not say anything about how this would happen. And the proposal suggests a DAO would be operational within 6 months, which seems unrealistic. I strongly encourage this proposer to come up with a more specific plan in the next fund, perhaps beginning with one or a few aspects of the food distribution system.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposer seems to have forgotten to include auditability criteria. The proposal includes the text "What success looks like:" and "Key Metrics:" but nothing following either. Without a detailed plan or metrics, I do not see how this proposal can be audited. Auditing would need to be entirely qualitative by analyzing progress towards a DAO, and that does not meet the approach of Catalyst. I suggest that the proposer re-submit a proposal with milestones or KPIs.

f6_assessments.q0: While a farm to table DAO is a great use case, my reading of the challenge is that the goal is creating a toolbox/framework for DAO's to incentivize their deployment on Cardano. Of course, every successful DAO implemented, if open sourced, will provide tools and examples for others behind them, but I think that this proposal doesn't exactly meet the challenge, so I'm giving it a neutral rating.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers seem to have a good network and  experience in food distribution, but they do not demonstrate the requisite technical skills to implement this challenge themselves. Only 15k of their budget is allocated to technical concerns which I believe may be insufficient to build what is a complex blockchain organization using outside labor and expertise.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability points/road map are not specific enough to audit the progress of the proposal, especially as regards technical development.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge by increasing the participation of farmers and local citizens in a DAO structure. This approach in this area is novel, particularly in the developed world, where supply chains are often overrun by agri-business and small, independent farmers and unable to compete. By integrating the DAO structure into the farming sector in the Pacific Northwest, this proposal has the potential to improve the transfer of fresh food from farm to table. Current co-ops and community groups that work in this space are left with few ways to encourage more individuals to participate and develop positive feedback loops where the products (and their quality) are managed in an iterative and communitarian manner. If successful, such a proof of concept could easily be extrapolated to other areas, and likely a variety of farm types.
f6_assessments.q1: While I am giving 3/5 I have to say that I am very impressed with the idea presented and do think that there is good potential. The reason why I feel unable to provide a higher ranking, is that the plan really does not explain what steps are needed to organize and develop a system in a feasible manner. There are no technical details on how they will go about setting up the DAO. While the roadmap does hint at some of the key steps that will need to be taken, there is no explanation of what that work will entail and how it will be conducted. For example, "Phase 1: 3 months:  Master Plan creation, basic architecture, and security plan" but there is no outline or even indication on what would be created. Given the amount  being asked for, I would need more details on the "how" aspects of the proposal. Love this idea though and strongly suggest addressing these issues in the future to increase chances.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately, I cannot discern from the proposal whether or not it could be audited by the community. While the proposers have a clear idea of the issue they want to solve, the plan is lacking significant details on how it would be rolled out. Within the "auditability" section of the proposal it's stated that auditing can happen at each step but there is no indication just how it would happen. Personally, I think that the proposers need to better explain a potential audit process (or how they'd like to encourage community audits) throughout the proposal, and if done appropriately, this would make it much stronger.

solution: Un colectivo regional autónomo de agricultores. Donde se aplican las normas, se garantiza la autenticidad y se reducen los costes de distribución.
experience: Soy un antiguo director general de un distribuidor de productos frescos. Activo en el espacio de la agricultura regenerativa. Empresario, constructor
